title-group.article-title: Parenteral Nutrition Amino Acids Product Shortage Considerations

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition
permissions.copyright-holder: The American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

body.p: During the amino acids shortage period, consider one or more of the following measures:

list-item.p: Assess each patient as to the indication for PN and provide nutrition via the oral or enteral route when possible.
Purchase only as much amino acid products supply as needed. In the interest of fair allocation to all patients nationally, please do not stockpile.
Use neonatal/pediatric-specific amino acids (or specialty amino acids) ONLY for their indicated patient populations.
Use high-concentration amino acid products (eg, >10%) sparingly. For example, save high-concentration amino acids for fluid-restricted patients requiring PN.

Compound PN in a single, central location (either in a centralized pharmacy or as outsourced preparation) to decrease inventory waste. Consider a supply outreach to other facilities in your geographic location.
Consider reviewing the entire portfolio of amino acid products available nationally. There may be a shortage in one concentration but availability in another. See Table 1 for a detailed listing.

Different brands of amino acid products are not always directly substitutable, especially for total nutrient admixture (3-in-1) vs dextrose/amino acids (2-in-1) PN formulations. They may have different pHs, different calcium-phosphorus solubilities, different amounts of phosphorus, and other characteristics that should be considered.
Assess your PN patient population to determine if a standardized, commercial PN product1 (“premix” PN) may be appropriate for a portion of your patient population.

Facilities and practitioners must continue to observe and be compliant with the product labeling (eg, package insert), USP General Chapter <797> Pharmaceutical Compounding–Sterile Preparations, and state boards of pharmacy rules and regulations.
Report severe drug product shortage information to the FDA Drug Shortage Program (http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DrugSafety/DrugShortages/ucm142398.htm).
Report any patient problems related to shortages to ISMP Medication Errors Reporting Program. To access that reporting mechanism, click here.

caption.p: Intravenous Amino Acid Products in the United States.

tr.td: Other; requirements related to complying with good manufacturing practices and discontinuation of the manufacture of the drug
Hospira suspended manufacturing all Aminosyn presentations in September 2012 for quality improvement.
BBraun discontinued several FreAmine presentations in October 2011. BBraun received FDA approval for an amino acid 15% solution that released in early June 2012.

td.bold: ProcalAmine (3% Specialty amino acids and 3% glycerin injection with electrolytes)

tr.td: Demand increase for the drug. Baxter is currently experiencing a backorder situation on presentation of Premasol due to unforeseen demand. Allocated availability continued through December 2012. Clinimix is a viable source of amino acids for most patients requiring parenteral nutrition.
Baxter is allocating many amino acid solutions in response to current market conditions. Clinimix or Clinimix E products are not affected.

td.bold: CLINIMIX E 2.75/5 (2.75% amino acid with electrolytes in 5% dextrose with calcium)
CLINIMIX E 2.75/10 (2.75% amino acid with electrolytes in 10% dextrose with calcium)
CLINIMIX E4.25/5 (4.25% amino acid with electrolytes in 5% dextrose with calcium)
CLINIMIX E 4.25/10 (4.25% amino acid with electrolytes in 10% dextrose with calcium)
CLINIMIX E 4.25/25 (4.25% amino acid with electrolytes in 25% dextrose with calcium)
CLINIMIX E 5/15 (5.0% amino acid with electrolytes in 15% dextrose with calcium)
CLINIMIX E 5/20 (5.0% amino acid with electrolytes in 20% dextrose with calcium)
CLINIMIX E 5/25 (5.0% amino acid with electrolytes in 25% dextrose with calcium)

fn.p: ASHP, American Society of Health-System Pharmacists; FDA, Food and Drug Administration; FDASIA, ; NDC, .Up-to-date information on drug shortages may be found at U.S. FDA, Current Drug Shortages A–D. Drug Safety and Availability: Drug Shortages (http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DrugSafety/DrugShortages/ucm314739.htm), and American Society of Health-System Pharmacists, Amino Acid Products: Current Shortages (http://www.ashp.org/DrugShortages/Current/bulletin.aspx?id=671).

body.p:
For the most up-to-date supply information, please see these websites:
American Society of Health-System Pharmacists (ASHP), Drug Shortages Resource Center (http://www.ashp.org/shortages?WT.ac=hp%5FPopLinks%5FDrug%5FShortages)
U.S. Food and Drug Administration, Drug Shortage Program, Current Drug Shortages (http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DrugSafety/DrugShortages/ucm050792.htm)
A.S.P.E.N. News section (http://www.nutritioncare.org/)

fn.label: Important Note:
fn.p: These recommendations do not constitute medical or professional advice, and should not be taken as such. To the extent the information published herein may be used to assist in the care of patients, this is the result of the sole professional judgment of the attending health professional whose judgment is the primary component of quality medical care.

Developed by the A.S.P.E.N. Intravenous Amino Acids National Shortage Task Force: Vincent W. Vanek, MD, FACS, CNSP (Chair); Jay Mirtallo, MS, RPh, BCNSP, FASHP; Larry Robinson, PharmD; Marty Kochevar, MS, RPh, BCNSP; and Peggi Guenter, PhD, RN, CNSN. (2010)

Revised by the A.S.P.E.N. CPC Shortage Subcommittee: Steve Plogsted, PharmD, BCNSP, CNSC (Chair); Gary Brooks, PharmD, BCPS, BCNSP; John DiBaise, MD; Antoinette Neal, RN, CRNI, CNSC, VA-BC; and Joseph Ybarra, Pharm D, BCNSP. Approved by the Clinical Practice Committee and the A.S.P.E.N. Board of Directors.
